80.text:
One of the biggest AI-driven titles of modern
times, Alien: Isolation brings the terror

85.text:
of the xenomorph to video games. While the
alien, LV-426 and many other key elements

91.text:
of the franchise have previously been explored,
Alien: Isolation takes a different route.

95.text:
A horror game steeped in the aesthetic and
style of Ridley Scott's classic 1979 movie:

100.text:
in which the player is trapped on the Sevastapol
space station with a sole intelligent, near-invincible

107.text:
alien. For this experience to play out as
expected, the alien itself has to carry a

112.text:
large amount of the experience: a demanding
feat for any AI in an industry in which non-player

117.text:
characters are either heavily scripted or
suffer really short life spans.

122.text:
So how did developers Creative Assembly pull
it off? The short answer is through tried

127.text:
and tested AI techniques, designed in a manner
that breaks from so many traditional game

131.text:
design concepts. So stay tuned as we dive
in and find out what it makes the Alien tick.

141.text:
The team behind Alien: Isolation built the
game around a simple premise: to survive an

151.text:
encounter with Ridley Scott's original alien.
Such a feat is pretty difficult to balance,

156.text:
given that you need a strong story to carry
the player through, but also to establish

160.text:
pacing such that the tension varies throughout
your gameplay. Neither of these are easy when

165.text:
you introduce a systemic AI into play: a collection
of decision making systems that react to what

170.text:
is happening in the game. It needs to know
when it can participate in the experience

174.text:
and it what level it should do so. In order
to do this, it required a unique design perspective.

182.text:
As explained by Andy Bray in his talk at the
nucl.ai conference, the player can't be scared

187.text:
shitless all the time, otherwise they'll just
give up. The tension had to vary but also

192.text:
maintain an air of unpredictability in the
xenomorph itself. This led to the developers

197.text:
seeking inspiration naturally from Ridley
Scott's Alien movie, but also looking classic

202.text:
horror movies as well adventure movies such
as Jurassic Park. The resulting philosophy,

208.text:
could be considered as 'psychopathic serendipity':
in which the alien always find itself in the

213.text:
right place at the right time. Even if you're
in hiding and the monster can't see you, and

219.text:
that it doesn't know your ultimate objective,
it will still find a way to mess with your

223.text:
plans. However, the key to pulling this off
was to ensure it wasn't scripted. Co-ordinated

228.text:
jump scares while fruitful the first time,
are cheap and don't yield any further reward

233.text:
in subsequent playthroughs. Instead, the player
should have a sense of powerlessness, but

237.text:
still know that while the alien is smart,
they are smarter.

241.text:
But all of this goes against the grain of
a lot of AAA games development: a world in

246.text:
which player empowerment is key. This means
challenging a lot of design tenets that have

251.text:
held in pretty much every Alien game - from
Alien 3 and Alien: Trilogy to Aliens: Colonial

258.text:
Marines. The biggest departure from previous
games, undoubtedly, is the fact that you cannot

263.text:
kill the alien. You can distract it and in
time find ways to hurt it and scare it off,

268.text:
but you cannot kill it. Ever. But in another
significant departure, there's something of

274.text:
a role reversal: the alien will not only kill
you frequently, but it does so with one hit.

280.text:
Ultimately, this creature must be a constant,
believable and threatening presence.

299.text:
In order for this alien to work, Creative
Assembly fell back on reliable and trusted

304.text:
AI techniques. Building systems that ensure
the alien serves its purpose, but interestingly,

309.text: also ensures it players according to expectations.

314.text:
To achieve this, the game requires two distinct
behaviour management systems: the director

319.text:
AI and the alien AI. The director AI observes
the player throughout the game: always watching,

328.text:
always knowing where you are. Meanwhile the
alien AI is driven by a series of sensors

334.text:
and behaviours that allow it to hunt down
and find the player. The director's job is

338.text:
to point the alien in the direction of the
player periodically, to give it a hint as

342.text:
to where it should be looking. Despite this,
the alien AI is never allowed to cheat: while

348.text:
the director always knows where you are, the
alien has to figure it out for itself. You

353.text:
can fool it, you can surprise it and you can
escape it.

357.text: But let's break this down in more detail...

361.text:
The director AI of Alien: Isolation was responsible
managing what was known as the menace gauge:

366.text:
a metric that allowed the system understand
how much it was pressuring the player. This

370.text:
is rather similar to an approach made in Left
4 Dead in which a stress gauge was used to

375.text:
prioritise enemy attacks. However in this
case, menace would come not from attacking

379.text:
the player, but being in their proximity and
thus ratchet up the tension.

384.text:
As such, the system would periodically wish
to invoke menace upon the player and tell

390.text:
the alien to head to a particular location.
While the alien is near the player, the menace

395.text:
gauge would increase depending on specific
factors: such as whether the creature is within

400.text:
a short walking distance of the player, whether
the palyer has actual line of sight and whether

404.text:
the alien was close on the motion tracker,
but could also reach the player quickly. This

409.text:
one is important, as the alien could technically
be close on the motion tracker but in another

413.text:
room. As such, the menace won't increase as
much given there is no real threat.

420.text:
Naturally once this menace metric has reached
too high a level, the director backs off and

424.text:
sends the alien elsewhere. Either into neighbouring
areas or up into the air vents. The general

430.text:
principle being that when the alien is closer,
the game is scarier, but we need to give players

435.text:
a break after a while. Not only to ensure
they stop freaking out, but to enable them

439.text: to achieve some progress in the game.

443.text:
This whole process is managed via a Job system
- previously used in the likes of BioShock:

448.text:
Infinite for the companion character Elizabeth
- which dictates the task to complete, the

453.text:
location the alien should visit and the priority
with which it should do so. The priority dictates

458.text:
to the alien whether it should finish what
it is doing now, immediately move towards

462.text:
doing this action (and blend the required
animations) or just outright interrupt everything

470.text:
The job system allows the alien to operate
in two main states of active and passive.

475.text:
The active state or front stage mode, is when
it is told to sweep areas of the map or search

480.text:
specific locations after a certain noise or
trigger occurred. Meanwhile the passive or

486.text:
backstage mode occurs once menace levels peak
for too long and it falls back into the air

490.text:
vents. But of course, it would then head for
air vents up ahead it thinks you're going

503.text:
So how do this translate into action execution?
Let's look at the xenomorph itself.

506.text:
The aliens behaviour is reliant upon behaviour
trees: a technique we've previously highlighted

510.text:
in our video on the AI of Halo. The monster
has over 100 nodes hidden within its behaviour

515.text:
tree system, with the top level of around
30 nodes responsible for selecting what type

520.text:
of behaviour it was about to execute. These
top level nodes would then have the alien

523.text:
execute within large sub-sections of the tree
responsible for specific sub-behaviours relating

530.text:
To add to this, certain parts of the behaviour
tree are - on starting the game - locked off.

536.text:
The system gradually unlocks these behaviours
in the tree as certain conditions are met

540.text:
throughout the game. This ensures that the
longer you play, that the alien starts to

545.text:
do exhibit new behavioural traits to keep
you on edge. In a sense, it gives the impression

549.text:
that the alien is beginning to learn from
experience, given the players behaviour is

553.text:
triggering the conditions that unlock it.
Though as Andy Bray was keen to point out:

560.text:
none of these conditions come from events
that lead to a players death. Otherwise the

564.text:
AI may develop an unfair advantage: given
you might never figure out what it is that

568.text:
it's learned from your behaviour, but also
that this game is designed for people to die

572.text:
in a lot and every time you do, this thing
would be getting smarter. One concession however,

577.text:
is there are triggers in the final build of
the game that unlock behaviours at specific

581.text:
points in your campaign if they haven't already,
that way the creature can keep pace with the

586.text: player as they begin to get better at playing.

592.text:
When given a specific job to complete from
the director, the alien is reliant upon a

596.text:
fast and efficient pathfinding system: whose
heuristics help to dictate the values of particular

601.text:
sensors the alien has. The alien has a variety
of sensors that allow it to identify with

606.text:
varying accuracy player footsteps when walking
or running, gunshots, and even the motion

611.text:
tracker when the player is around 1.5 meters
away. Now the question that burned in my mind

617.text:
when I played it was whether the alien had
sensors built into the tail, so as to ensure

621.text:
you don't try and step on it. The answer is
actually no, but in a sneaky move by Creative

626.text:
Assembly, the alien has very, very short range
sensors that look behind it. It quite literally

632.text:
has eyes in the back of its head, I am told
with the intention of ensuring that players

638.text:
do not avoid detection by walking around behind
it.

642.text:
So the last real thing to cover is itthe aliens
movement patterns: those who have played alien

649.text:
isolation will know that the alien is prone
to pacing around an environment for seldom

653.text:
minutes. This thing isn't moving towards a
specific location in an optimal fashion; it's

658.text:
searching, it's hunting. This is achieved
by giving the alien particular areas of interest

663.text:
- either those hand tuned by designers or
generated dynamically in the environment - to

668.text:
head for. Sometimes these are specific locations
the designers want the alien to visit, and

674.text:
other times it's responding to players given
they made too much noise. A perimeter of nearby

680.text:
locations is established and the alien will
devise a path to visit them all in a travelling

685.text:
salesman fashion - meaning it will visit every
point, but not with any guarantee it does

688.text:
so in an optimal fashion, given it's they
are prioritised based on their visiblity by

693.text:
the alien. This sub-optimal execution results
periodically in the alien backtracking on

700.text:
itself: a behaviour designed on purpose to
give the impression it's double checking or

704.text:
doubting itself. These locations are separated
into search locations: those that the alien

709.text:
will visit, and spot locations: where it will
stay where it is currently standing and then

713.text:
turn to look at the area of interest. For
safety, the designers were able to dictate

718.text:
specific areas the alien never looks, so as
it doesn't catch you out in unfair situations.

726.text:
Considering all this design effort, you'd
be quick to think that despite it all, the

730.text:
game designers would still allow for the alien
AI to cheat periodically by either teleporting

735.text:
or being clairvoyant in its knowledge. According
to Bray, this is categorically untrue. Throughout

741.text:
the entire 12-18 hour campaign, the alien
only teleports twice to be in very specific

746.text:
locations and is only done to enable it appear
in cutscenes.

757.text:
Alien: Isolation is an achievement: an AI-driven
game that holds your attention for the most

770.text:
part through the experience of interacting
a primary antagonist. A real feat in an of

777.text:
itself, the fact that this is then achieved
within the context of a horror game is all

781.text:
the more impressive. Fortunately this was
largely agreed upon by critics, who hailed

785.text:
the alien and it's AI behaviour as a real
driving force behind the game and certainly

790.text:
worth checking out if you haven't done so
already (I mean seriously, if you're watching

793.text:
this channel, just play the games I tell you
to, doctors orders!).

796.text:
We're only just cracking the surface of how
this system works. For those more tech savvy,

801.text:
be sure to catch the full talk by Andy Bray
from nucl.ai. My personal thanks to both Andy

808.text:
as well as Derek Fagan from Creative Assembly
who were kind enough to humour me and answer

812.text: some questions I had about the game.

821.text:
With that we bring this video to a close,
I'm Tommy Thompson and this has been AI and

825.text:
Games: a series that doesn't happen without
the help and support of our sponsors listed

829.text:
now on patreon.com. Thanks for watching and
we'll see you all next time!
